pullRequest.body:
Show that if M is a flat module over a local ring, then every family that is linearly independent over the residue field is also linearly independent over the local ring. As a consequence, if M is moreover finite, then M is free.

---

If M is of finite presentation, then it suffices to assume `𝔪 ⊗ M → M` is injective to conclude that M is free; see [Module.free_of_maximalIdeal_rTensor_injective](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/LocalRing/Module.html#Module.free_of_maximalIdeal_rTensor_injective). This does not work if M is only assumed to be finite: simply take M to be the residue field k. If the maximal ideal 𝔪 is not finitely generated, then M = k is not finitely presented, in particular not free. However, if `𝔪 ⊗ k = 𝔪 ⧸ 𝔪 ^ 2` is zero, then `𝔪 ⊗ k → k` is definitely injective. `𝔪 = 𝔪 ^ 2` is precisely the setting of almost mathematics, and examples include the ring of integers in $\overline{\mathbb{Q}_p}$.

It's interesting to work out how flatness fail in this case: `I ⧸ 𝔪I = I ⊗ k → k = R ⧸ 𝔪` is injective means that `𝔪I = 𝔪 ⊓ I = I` (if `I ≠ ⊤`), which happens precisely when `I` is not finitely generated (i.e. when `I` consists of elements with valuation > some nonnegative real number, rather than ≥ some rational number). In other words, injectivity fails precisely at the f.g. ideals (= principal since R is Bezout). By well-known flatness criterion (mathlib definition), if injectivity holds at f.g. ideals it also holds at non-f.g. ideals, and it's interesting to know it can happen that it fails at all f.g. ideals but still could hold at all non-f.g. ideals.

- [x] depends on: #20452

</details>

* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20452~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

```suggestion
/-- The linear isomorphism corresponding to a matrix with 1 on the diagonal
and all other nonzero entries on the same row. -/
def Finsupp.addSubEquiv (i : ι) (c : ι → R) (h₀ : c i = 0) : (ι →₀ R) ≃ₗ[R] (ι →₀ R) := by
```
Since it depends on non-trivial input, I think it is more readable to repeat these here.

Also I find the docstring hard to parse, how do you like:
```
/-- Given `c : ι → R` and an index `i` such that `c i = 0`, this is the linear isomorphism sending
the `j`-th standard basis vector to itself plus `c j` multiplied with the `i`-th standard basis vector. -/
```

Finally, what is the reasoning behind `addSubEquiv` as the name? The linear map induced by [Matrix.transvection](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Matrix/Transvection.html#Matrix.transvection) is a special case of this, right?

```suggestion
  rw [← Submodule.comap_linearEquivToLinearMap, ← LinearMap.ker_comp]
  convert rTensor_mkQ Q I
  · ext; simp
  rw [← Submodule.comap_linearEquivToLinearMap]
  rw [Submodule.comap_equiv_eq_map_symm, Submodule.map_linearEquivToLinearMap]
  rw [Submodule.map_symm_eq_iff, Submodule.map_range_rTensor_subtype_lid]
```
If you add
```

@[simp]
lemma Submodule.comap_linearEquivToLinearMap {R M N : Type*} [Semiring R]
    [AddCommMonoid M] [AddCommMonoid N] [Module R M] [Module R N]
    (f : M ≃ₗ[R] N) (p : Submodule R N) :
    p.comap f.toLinearMap = p.comap f :=
  rfl

@[simp]
lemma Submodule.map_linearEquivToLinearMap {R M N : Type*} [Semiring R]
    [AddCommMonoid M] [AddCommMonoid N] [Module R M] [Module R N]
    (f : M ≃ₗ[R] N) (p : Submodule R M) :
    p.map f.toLinearMap = p.map f :=
  rfl
```
I couldn't get these to work with `LinearEquivClass`, but maybe that is possible.
Also this `erw` can be eliminated using the lemmas from above.
Can you use `induction s using Finset.induction generalizing v` instead of the `revert v` and later `intro x hx`?

pullRequest.title: feat(LocalRing/Module): fg flat module over a local ring is free
